```json
{
  "paper_metadata": {
    "title": "Graduation impacts of social protection programmes in Africa: Evidence from Rwanda",
    "matches_expected_title": "NO"
  },
  "program_information": {
    "program_name": "Enhancing the Productive Capacity of Extremely Poor People (Graduation Programme)",
    "country": "Rwanda",
    "region": "Southern Province",
    "target_population": "Extremely poor households"
  },
  "intervention_components": {
    "component_a_cash_support": {
      "component_a_present": true,
      "cash_support_type": "unconditional cash transfers",
      "cash_amount": "RwF18,000 per month (US$26)",
      "cash_frequency": "monthly for a minimum of 12 months",
      "is_loan_or_credit": "NO",
      "cash_evidence_citation": "All 1,200 households received cash transfers from Concern Worldwide for a minimum of 12 months. The average value of cash transfers was RwF18,000 per month (US$26), based on the number of dependants in the household."
    },
    "component_b_assets": {
      "component_b_present": true,
      "assets_provided": ["livestock (cows, goats, chickens, pigs)", "productive assets"],
      "direct_provision": "YES",
      "assets_evidence_citation": "Instead of employment on Public Works projects, participants receive intensive training and coaching and a productive asset that is expected to generate future streams of income even after project support ends. | The situation for livestock is different: as for the first and second cohorts, we find significant increases in the number of livestock owned over time as a result of the Graduation Programme."
    }
  },
  "study_characteristics": {
    "outcomes_measured": [
      "consumption/expenditure",
      "income/earnings",
      "food security/nutrition",
      "asset accumulation",
      "education",
      "health",
      "social cohesion",
      "savings/financial",
      "well-being"
    ],
    "outcomes_evidence_citation": "Findings reveal that participants have significantly reduced their level of deprivation and demonstrated improvements in consumption, health, education and social participation. | Positive changes in the circumstances of participants were expected, as cash transfers increase the purchasing power of individuals and enable investment in assets and in income-generating activities. Incremental income also allows households to invest in the health and education of family members, thereby improving their wellbeing, especially for children, both immediately and in the future. | For the first cohort, participants actually doubled their average level of consumption asset ownership, from 3.4 to 6.9 points (equivalent to an increase of 3.4 distinct assets)."
    ,
    "study_design": "Quasi-experimental (difference-in-differences)",
    "design_evidence_citation": "The evaluation of Rwanda's Graduation Programme uses a quasi-experimental research design -the research is designed to share the logic of an experiment but recognises that we cannot control for all the interventions and changes in people's lives. | Difference-in-differences analysis was performed to compare participants and control group households after the cash transfers phase.",
    "is_review_or_policy_analysis": false,
    "publication_year": null,
    "study_conducted_year": "2011-2013",
    "sample_size": 1200,
    "completed": true
  },
  "bonus_information": {
    "has_qualitative_components": true,
    "qualitative_methods": ["in-depth interviews", "case studies", "focus groups"],
    "qualitative_evidence_citation": "The qualitative data provide context, texture and explanatory depth to the quantitative findings. Specifically, the qualitative research highlights changes in the lives and livelihoods of programme participants over time; focusing on the enabling factors and challenges for change as expressed by the participants themselves. In-depth discussions generate information that enables programme implementers to understand participants' perceptions about the changes taking place in their lives. | This was complemented by qualitative research conducted a few months later to explore changes in indicators during the first year of implementation, as well as in-depth interviews with case study households, for a deeper understanding of the 'enablers' and 'constrainers' of graduation.",
    "has_cost_data": false,
    "cost_mentions": null,
    "cost_evidence_citation": null
  },
  "evidence_citations": {
    "program_name_citation": "This article examines graduation impacts of social protection programmes in Africa, by presenting evidence from an interim evaluation of the 'Enhancing the Productive Capacity of Extremely Poor People' project, implemented by Concern Worldwide in Rwanda's Southern Province.",
    "country_citation": "This article examines graduation impacts of social protection programmes in Africa, by presenting evidence from an interim evaluation of the 'Enhancing the Productive Capacity of Extremely Poor People' project, implemented by Concern Worldwide in Rwanda's Southern Province.",
    "target_population_citation": "The project targets households that would normally be eligible for Direct Support from the VUP, and aims to demonstrate that these households can also be assisted to 'graduate' out of extreme poverty if they receive an appropriate package of assistance which includes, but extends beyond, regular unconditional cash transfers."
  }
}
```
